variant.question: During your approach with thunderstorms in the vicinity, you notice that the visibility has dropped below minimum. This is a(n) ... and it can be ... by a proper briefing.

options.text: Threat, predicted
Error, eliminated
Threat, eliminated
Error, predicted

variant.question:
Man possesses a system for maintaining his internal equilibrium in the face of variations brought about by external stimulations
This internal equilibrium is called

options.text: Homeostasis
Heterostasis
Isothermy
Metastasis

variant.question:
Complete the following statement:
During an approach with thunderstorms in the vicinity, the pilot notices that the visibility has dropped below minimum. This is a/an (1)__ and it can be (2)__ by a proper briefing.

options.text: (1) Threat; (2) predicted.
(1) Error; (2) eliminated.
(1) Error; (2) predicted.
(1) Threat; (2) eliminated.

variant.question: The state of knowing where the aircraft is, where it has been, and where it is going is called

options.text: situational awareness.
vigilance.
risk area awareness.
safety awareness.

variant.question: In the initial phase of flight training the relationship between confidence and expertise can be described as:

options.text: The pilot is competent enough to fly the aircraft at this stage, but does neither have a great deal of confidence in his/her abilities nor in the whole system.
During this learning stage, the pilot is very near to achieving full potential knowledge of the machine.
The pilot has a sphere of expertise which is reduced to daily use of his skills.
The pilot is sufficiently competent to fly and knows at this stage what he can and cannot do.

variant.question: Whilst en-route to the destination, the Commander, who is flying the aircraft, briefs on the correct approach procedure, with the Co-pilot monitoring height and speed on the approach. During the approach for landing, the flight crew inadvertently allowed the speed to increase above that required by the published approach procedure. This situation is an example of:

options.text: A handling error by the Commander and a procedural error by the Co-Pilot.
A handling error by the Commander and communication error by the Co-Pilot.
A procedural error by the Commander and a standard operating procedure error by the Co-Pilot.
Procedural errors by both pilots.

State the sources how orientation is achieved.1. Eyes  
2. Middle ear  
3. Semi-circular canals  
4. Seat-of-the-pants-sense
Angular accelerations are perceived by:

options.text: the semi circular canals.
the otoliths.
the cochlea.
the receptors in the skin and the joints.

variant.question: Illuminated anti-collision lights in IMC

options.text: can cause disorientation.
will improve the pilot’s depth perception.
will effect the pilot’s binocular vision.
can cause colour-illusions.

variant.question: During flight in IMC, the most reliable sense which should be used to overcome illusions is the:

options.text: visual sense, interpreting the attitude indicator.
visual sense by looking outside.
seat-of-the-pants sense.
vestibular sense.

variant.question: A pilot accustomed to landing on a wide runway may find, when approaching to a narrow runway, that he/she is at a..

options.text: greater height than he/she actually is, with the tendency to land short.
lower height than he/she actually is, with the tendency to overshoot.
lower height and the impression of landing slow.
greater height and the impression of landing short.

variant.question: The visual approach to a high altitude aerodrome requires a relatively tight right turn, to avoid highground to the left. When lined up with the runway, the approach continues over terrain that slopes down to the runway threshold. What visual illusion could be associated with this approach?

options.text: The proximity to the terrain below the aircraft, when at the correct height for the approach, can create the illusion that the aircraft is too low; the pilot might reduce the rate of descent and land beyond the normal touchdown point.

The proximity to the terrain during the approach can create the illusion that the aircraft is too low and, in response, the pilot could reduce the approach speed and fly a flatter approach, risking to land short of the normal touchdown area.

The slope of the terrain down to the threshold can create an illusion that the rate of descent is too high and, in attempting to correct for the illusion, the pilot could make the approach more shallow and land short of the runway.

The late view of the terrain below the aircraft, on completion of the right turn, can create the illusion that the aircraft has increased height during the turn and, in response to this illusion, the pilot could make the descent steeper and land short.

variant.question: Linear acceleration when flying straight and level in IMC may give the illusion of...

options.text: climbing.
spinning.
yawing.
descending.

variant.question: Vision of terrain relief (e.g. hills, valleys, etc.):

options.text: is based on binocular vision at short distances and the rules of proportion and perspective for objects that are further away
is possible at only at distances over 200 m due to binocular vision
is impossible if a pilot wears sunglasses
is impossible with only one eye

variant.question: Vision of terrain relief (e.g. hills, valleys, etc.):

options.text: is based on binocular vision at short distances and the rules of proportion and perspective for objects that are further away.
is impossible if a pilot wears sunglasses.
is impossible with only one eye.
is possible only at distances over 200 m due to binocular vision.

variant.question: You are approaching over water to a runway which lies perpendicular to the shore. The sky is blue and cloudless. What will be your perception?

options.text: You may experience a black hole illusion, so you need to rely on your instruments.
You feel like being too low, which may result in a long landing.
You feel like being too high, which may result in a short landing.
You have no perception of height and need to rely on your altitude indicator.

variant.question: A "Graveyard spin" is:

options.text: a spin in which the pilot, on recovery, tends to re-enter the spin due to the somatogyral illusion where the vestibular system no longer senses radial acceleration.
an illusion caused by misperception of being higher than you really are when performing a spin. Thus the recovery tends to be dangerously low.
a spin manoeuvre that should only be performed by well trained pilots.
a fatal accident caused by a state of spinning the fluid in the brain.

variant.question: Being pressed into the seat can cause illusions and/or false reactions in a pilot lacking visual contact to the ground, because this sensation:

options.text: corresponds with the sensation a pilot gets when starting a climb or performing a level turn.
will not stimulate the seat-of-the-pants sense.
makes the pilot to pull up the nose to compensate for level flight.
corresponds with the sensation a pilots gets, when flying straight and level or starting a descent.

variant.question: When flying in gradually deteriorating visual conditions, what strategy will help the pilot to avoid spatial disorientation?

options.text: Rely increasingly on the indications of the flight instruments.
Keep head and eye movements to a minimum.
Trust the body’s kinaesthetic sense of movement.
Reduce environmental factors such as stress and distractions.

variant.question: During poor weather conditions a pilot should fly with reference to instruments because..

options.text: perception of distance and speed is difficult in an environment of low contrast.
pressure differences can cause the altimeter to give wrong information.
his/her attention will be distracted automatically under these conditions.
“the danger of a “greying out” will make it impossible to determine the height above the terrain.

variant.question: How can a pilot prevent the effects of the black hole illusion when flying VFR at night?

options.text: Avoid making a straight and long approach.
Make regular turns on the approach to see the ground below the aircraft clearly.
Only begin the approach descent when the runway lights are visible.
Turn on the landing gear lights.

variant.question: Positive linear acceleration when flying in IMC may cause a false sensation of..

options.text: pitching up.
pitching down.
the sideward movement of objects in the field of vision.
vertigo.

variant.question:
A pilot approaching a runway which is narrower than normal may feel he/she is at a greater height than he/she actually is
To compensate he/she may fly a

options.text: flatter than normal approach with the tendency to undershoot.
higher than normal approach with the tendency to overshoot.
compensatory glide path and land long.
compensatory glide path and stall out.

variant.question: Vertigo is the result of:

options.text: A blockage of the outer or middle ear; e.g. ear wax, fluid in the middle ear.
A combination of lifestyle (e.g. smoking) and environmental factors (e.g. stress).
Infectious diseases of the inner ear which affects balance and hearing.
Frequent exposure to prolonged noise of high frequency, e.g. turbine and engine noise.

variant.question:
How can a pilot overcome vertigo, encountered during a real or simulated instrument flight?

1. Establish and maintain an effective instrument cross-check.2. Always believe the instruments3. Ignore arising illusions.4. Move the head sidewards and back and forth to "shake-off" illusions.

options.text: 1, 2, and 3 are correct, 4 is false
1 and 4 are correct, 2 and 3 are false
never trust your sense of feeling
1 and 2 are correct, 3 and 4 are false

variant.question: When the weather is foggy on approach, a pilot may get the impression that...

options.text: the airfield is further away than it actually is.
his/her eyes are focusing on infinity.
his/her visual field is shrinking -i.e. tunnel vision-.
the aircraft’s altitude is lower than it actually is.

variant.question: While flying VFR "wings level" on top of clouds at 10000 feet, your artificial horizon indicates a 20 degree bank.

options.text: You trust the instrument and level off according to the instrument read-out.
No attitude correction is needed since you know that your vision is more reliable than the instrument with regards to spatial orientation.
You take the proper action by “leaning” toward the lower end of the artificial horizon, thus compensating for the perceptional illusion.
You pull the circuit breaker to the artificial horizon knowing that perceptional illusions called “leans” might severely impair your control of the aircraft.

variant.question:
A pilot is used to landing on small and narrow runways only
Approaching a larger and wider runway can lead to

options.text: an early or high “round out”.
a flatter-than-normal approach with the risk of “ducking under”
a risk of landing short of the overrun.
a steeper-than-normal approach, dropping low.

options.text: high approach with overshoot.
high approach with undershoot.
low approach with overshoot.
low approach with undershoot.

variant.question: In flight, pilots can be affected by sensory illusion during:

options.text: a spin at night.
a spin in the afternoon.
a spin at daytime.
constant level flight with wings not levelled.

variant.question: What can cause spatial disorientation?

options.text: False perception of orientation of the aircraft with respect to spatial references.
Flying in clear daylight conditions.
Damage to the receptor cells in the eyes.
Reference to well-defined external visual references, such as the horizon.

variant.question: Without visual reference, what illusion could the pilot get, when he is stopping the rotation to recover from a spin? He will get the illusion of:

options.text: spinning into the opposite direction.
straight and level flight.
spinning into the same direction.
climbing and turning into the original direction of the spin.

variant.question:
Orientation in flight is accomplished by the:

1. eyes2. middle ear3. semicircular canals4. seat-of-the-pants sense

options.text: 1, 3 and 4 only are correct
3 and 4 only are correct
1 only is correct
1 and 4 only are correct

variant.question:
During a VFR flight, visibility deteriorates and the pilot, who doesnt hold an instrument rating, encounters cloud conditions, despite the degrading meteorological conditions the pilot decides not to divert but to continue the VFR flight, finally entering Instrumental Meteorological Conditions, the pilot attempts to continue the planned route but after 5 minutes contacts ATC for assistance. Which of the following are accetable explanation for why the pilot made violation?
1. The pilot did not properly assess the risk of the spatial disorientation while entering into IMC.2. The pilot made poor assesment of the environmental situation, and as a consequence the pilot inadvertently entered IMC.3. Once the conditions reached IMC, the pilot reviewed the options. There is time to re-evaluate the situation in a degraded visual environmental before experiencing the spatial disorientation.4. The pilot failed to get an accurate meteorological pre-flight briefing, the development of options when encountering an unexpected situation takes time and may delay reaching a desicion.

options.text: 1, 2 and 4
2 and 3 only
2, 3 and 4
1 and 4 only

variant.question:
State the conditions which cause the black hole effect and the danger to flight safety
The black hole effect can be caused by flying

options.text: over water at night on the approach to an airfield which can create the illusion that the aircraft is at a higher altitude than it really is, leading to a low approach being flown.
under instruments with poor cockpit lighting and can lead to disorientation.
over water at night on the approach to an airfield which can create the illusion that the aircraft is at a higher altitude than it really is, leading to a high approach being flown.
over featureless terrain on the approach to an airfield which can create the illusion that the aircraft is at a higher altitude than it really is, leading to a high approach being flown.

variant.question: The Leans or somatogyral illusion can be caused by;

options.text: reducing bank following a prolonged turn.
bunting the aircraft.
a carrier take-off.
going into a turn too quickly.

variant.question: When might a pilot have the sensation of a nose-low attitude?

options.text: When rapidly decelerating in straight, horizontal flight.
During angular acceleration.
When carrying out a sustained, gentle turn.
When rapidly accelerating in straight, horizontal flight.

variant.question: When might a pilot have the sensation of a nose-low attitude?

options.text: When rapidly decelerating in straight, horizontal flight.
When rapidly accelerating in straight, horizontal flight.
During a sustained, gentle turn.
During angular acceleration.

variant.question: The so-called 'Seat-of-the-Pants' sense is?

options.text: unsuitable for spatial orientation when outside visual references are lost.
the only sense a pilot can rely on, when flying in IMC.
only to be used by experienced pilots with the permission to fly in IMC.
useful for instrument and contact flight.

variant.question: If you are subjected to an illusion during night flying you should:

options.text: rely on instruments.
dim the cockpit lighting.
scan the surroundings.
use your oxygen mask.

variant.question: On experiencing a vestibular illusion in straight and level flight, it is recommended that..

options.text: you avoid head movements and rely on your instruments.
you close your eyes for a moment so that the oculo-vestibular conflict disappears.
you rely on your sensations only, as humans are much more reliable than flight instruments.
you tilt your head to the side opposite to the turn to nullify the stimulus causing the illusion.

variant.question: Spatial disorientation will be most likely to occur during flight..

options.text: if the brain receives conflicting information and the pilot does not believe the instruments.
when flying in bright sunlight above a cloud layer.
when flying in light rain below the ceiling.
when flying in and out of clouds and the pilot maintains good instrument cross check.

variant.question: An aerodrome lies close to the southern outskirts of a bigger city. North of that city, the terrain is rising steeply to a mountain ridge. You are approaching the aerodrome from the south, over a vast, unpopulated desert. Which illusion could arise during the approach?

options.text: When approaching VFR at night, the pilot may get the impression of being at a greater height than he actually is, because the relative position of the light in his windscreen is lower than expected. He may descend too soon and land short of the runway.

When flying VFR both at night or day, the pilot may be affected by the black hole illusion, because the relative position of the runway lights in the windscreen is higher than expected. He may fly too high on approach and may have to perform a very steep descent.

Due to the lack o visual cues, the pilot could have the impression that his aircraft is too low, which is supported by the relative position of the approach lights in front of the lights from the city behind it. His descent may be too shallow and he may overshoot the runway.
When approaching VFR at night, the flight path over the dark desert may produce the illusion of being too low. The pilot may descend too slowly and overshoot the runway, or he may have to go around.

variant.question:
A pilot flies an approach in hazy weather conditions, and has some difficulties recognising the runway features. Due to the visual conditions, the pilot has the perception of being farther, i.e, at a greater distance, from the runway than he/she actually is.
What is the illusion, and which danger is associated with it?

options.text: Size constancy: the pilot tends to hold a constant altitude when he/she should be descending.
Surface planes: the pilot tends to fly turns because he/she fails to identify the runway features.
Atmospheric perspective: the pilot tends to fly a higher approach, landing long.
Autokinesis: the pilot tends to fly the aircraft towards a single light reference.

variant.question: What illusion may occur if an aircraft is flying into fog, snow or haze?

options.text: Objects seem to be farther away than in reality.
Objects will appear closer than they really are.
Objects will appear bigger in size than in reality.
Objects will appear to be static.

variant.question: What illusion may occur if an airplane is flying into fog, snow or haze?

options.text: Objects seem to be further away than in reality.
Objects seem to move slower than in reality.
Objects will appear bigger in size than in reality.
Objects will appear closer than they really are.

variant.question: During flight a pilot may get illusions about the pitch and bank angle. This is caused by the wrong interpretation of signals from the vestibular apparatus. What is an element of the vestibular apparatus?

options.text: The anterior semicircular canals.
The cochlea in the inner ear.
The ossicles.
The ear drum in the ear canal.

is a natural human instinct which will always indicate the correct body position in space.

variant.question: The risk of getting a spatial disorientation is growing when:

options.text: there is contradictory information between the instruments and the vestibular organs.
the pilot is buckled too tight to his seat and cannot sense the attitude changes of the aircraft by his seat-of-the-pants sense.
the pilot is performing an effective instrument cross-check and is ignoring illusions.
information from the vestibular organ in the inner ear are ignored.

variant.question: The visibility during a VFR flight gets worse and the pilot does not have an instrument rating. However, the pilot does not divert and tries to continue VFR but finally enters clouds (IMC). The pilot still tries to continue the planned track but contacts ATC for assistance after a few minutes. Which of the following statements refer to acceptable explanations for the pilots violation? - The pilot did not properly assess the risk of spatial disorientation while entering IMC. - The pilot made a poor assessment of the environmental situation, and as a consequence the pilot inadvertently entered IMC. - Once the conditions reached IMC, the pilot reviewed the options. There is time to re-evaluate the situation in a degraded visual environment before experiencing spatial disorientation. - The pilot failed to get an accurate meteorological pre-flight briefing. The development of options when encountering an unexpected situation takes time and may delay reaching a decision.
What illusion can you expect when landing on a larger runway than you are used to?

options.text: You flare too high.
You undershoot the runway.
You land short.
You flare too low.

variant.question: A student pilot is seated in a rotating chamber without any outside visual reference. He is told to move his head up and down slowly. Soon he starts to feel dizzy and nausea sets in. Why does this happen?

options.text: Coriolis effect
Black hole effect
Flicker vertigo
Spatial disorientation

variant.question: On an approach, by day, in snowy conditions, without reference to glide slope information..

options.text: judgement of height is extremely difficult.
there is a risk of you entering a spin.
pilots tend to estimate the distance to touch down as shorter than in reality.
estimation of height and distance is not a problem for a well-trained pilot.

blood rushing into legs.

variant.question: Suppose you make an approach to a runway which is narrower than standard. Which of the following errors are you likely to commit?

options.text: Initiate a flare too late.
Not following the VASIs.
Initiate a flare too early.

variant.question: Flickering light when reflected from spinning rotor blades..

options.text: can cause spatial disorientation and/or nausea.
should be avoided, because it may destroy the optic nerve.
can be avoided when the strobe-lights are switched on.
has no effect.

variant.question: Which of the following illusions are brought about by conflicts between the visual system and the vestibular system ? 1. Illusions concerning the attitude of the aircraft 2. Autokinetic illusion (when a fixed point is viewed as moving) 3. Illusions when estimating the size and distance of objects 4. Illusions of rotation

options.text: 1 and 4
3 and 4

variant.question: A pilot is on a VFR flight above a dense layer of fog, with bright light coming from above. The visibility is above 10 km and the sky is clear. Select the correct statement.

options.text: Even healthy eyes will experience difficulties in this situation for lack of objects to focus on.
Particularly long-sighted pilots will experience difficulties in this situation.
Empty field myopia will make it quite hard to detect objects moving left or right.
Particularly short-sighted pilots will experience difficulties in this situation.

variant.question: Which system(s) should be trusted during flight through clouds and instrument meteorological conditions (IMC)?

options.text: Visual.
Vestibular.
Proprioceptive.
Combined function of all senses.

variant.question: An aerodrome is located near to the southern edge of a large town. Directly to the north of the town, there is a high mountain. The approach to the aerodrome is straight-in, from the south, over a large unpopulated desert. What hazard should the pilots be aware of when approaching the aerodrome?

options.text: In night VFR, the visual illusion of being too high due to the runway lights appearing to be in a lower position than expected on the windscreen, and the risk of descending too early and landing short.

The absence of visual cues can give the illusion that the aircraft is too low, this illusion can be reinforced at night by the relative position of the approach lights in front of the background light of the populated areas, with the risk of descending too slowly and overshooting the runway.

In day or night VFR, the possibility of suffering from the "black hole" illusion, where the runway lights appear in the pilot's windshield at a higher position than is expected, with the risk of being too high on the approach and making a very steep descent.
In night VFR, over the dark desert, the visual illusion of being too low, with the risk of descending too slowly and overshooting the runway, and even attempting to go around.

variant.question: Flying a daytime visual approach with reduced visibility due to fog, rain or haze can give the illusion that the aircraft is..

options.text: at a greater distance from the runway than it actually is, and the pilot tends to fly a shallow glide path and land long.
lower than it actually is on the approach, and the pilot risks landing long and overshooting the runway by staying higher.
closer to the runway than it actually is, and the pilot has a tendency to fly a much steeper approach.
faster than it actually is on the approach, and the pilot risks reducing power too early and landing short of the runway.

variant.question: You are approaching to a runway over a continuously rising terrain. What illusion can you expect?

options.text: False horizon
Empty field myopia
Autokinesis
Size constancy

variant.question: An aircraft is approaching over an upsloping terrain towards a flat runway. What illusion may this cause?

options.text: The pilot may think that he/she is too high and therefore, he/she will increase the rate of descent, which will result in a shallow approach.
The pilot may think that he/she is too fast and decrease power.
The pilot may think that he/she is too slow and increase power.
The pilot may think that he/she is too low and therefore, he/she will decrease the rate of descent, which will result in a steep approach.

spatial disorientation, autokinesis illusion, graveyard spiral

variant.question: All human senses are prone to often competing sensory inputs that can create illusions and be misleading in determining the pilot's spatial orientation. Is this statement correct or incorrect and why?

options.text: Correct, because we normally trust vision as our primary and most accurate sense, even when other sensory inputs are conflicting.
Incorrect, because interaction between the senses is coordinated by the brain, which is able to distinguish between correct and incorrect sensory inputs.
Incorrect, because each sensory input acts independently as a standalone input; therefore, the spatial orientation of a pilot is not affected.
Correct, because we habitually trust all senses equally, which can disturb our sensory system when all sensory inputs seem equally strong.

variant.question: Which procedure is recommended to prevent or overcome spatial disorientation?

variant.question:
An aircraft is making a visual approach to an aerodrome with a runway that is narrower than normal. The runway slopes up from the touchdown area until near to the stop end.
What illusion(s) could the runway's dimensions and slope lead to, when the aircraft is lined up for an approach to this aerodrome?

options.text: The illusion that the aircraft is higher on the approach than it should be, with the risk of flying a steeper than normal approach and landing short of the touchdown area.

Initially the illusion that the aircraft is higher on the approach than it should be, but because the runway is also sloping up towards the stop end, the illusion in the later stages of the approach of the aircraft being too low. Overall there is a risk that a steeper approach is made followed by a late flare by the pilot.

The illusion that the aircraft is too low on the approach with the risk of flying at a shallower angle than normal and of landing beyond the touchdown area. In addition, the narrow width could cause the pilot to misjudge the height above the runway and make a heavy landing.
The runway slope should NOT influence the pilot's perception, but narrowness of the runway could give the illusion of being too low, with the risk that the flare is executed later than normal.

variant.question: In case of spatial disorientation...

options.text: vision remains our most important source of information, even if we receive conflicting data from other sources.
visual information suddenly become useless and have to be actively disregarded.
perceptions of all senses have the same impact, which makes it difficult to manage sensory conflicts.
information on orientation can only be acquired visually. Pilots should aim to get a good view of the horizon.

variant.question: The area in front of a runway threshold descends towards the threshold. Possible danger is:

options.text: approach is lower than normal and may result in a short landing.
approach is higher than normal and may result in a long landing.
to drop far below the glide path.
to misjudge the length of the runway.

options.text: being too high and too far away, dropping low and landing short.
climbing.
being too close, landing long.
being too low, flying a steeper approach than normal.

indicate the difference between gravity and G-forces.

options.text: to overestimate his/her height.
to misjudge the attitude of the aircraft.
the black hole effect.

variant.question: When approaching a flat runway on top of a steady upslope...

options.text: the pilot believes to be high and tends to increase the rate of descent. So the first part of the approach will be steeper and the final part will be shallower. The result will be a short landing.
the pilot believes to be too fast and decreases power.
the pilot believes to be too slow and increases power.
the pilot believes to be low and tends to increase the rate of descent. So the first part of the approach will be steeper and the final part will be shallower. The result will be a short landing.

variant.question: A pilot is approaching a runway which is narrower than the one at their home base and has more of an upslope. What visual impression may the pilot get during the approach, and how should they proceed safely?

options.text: The pilot may have the impression that they are above the correct approach path, resulting in an increased rate of descent and possible undershoot. They should believe their instruments.

The pilot will be able to correctly assess their relative position and speed, but may be unaware of the increased landing distance required. They should consult their performance charts before the flight to ensure that the aircraft can safely land at the aerodrome.
The pilot may believe that they are flying too fast, resulting in an early thrust reduction and lack of energy. They should be careful not to reduce below the specified approach speed.
The pilot will feel that they are further out on the descent path and may reduce thrust too late, resulting in an overshoot. They should pay careful attention to their approach speed.

variant.question: Approaches at night without visual references on the ground and no landing aids (e.g. VASIS) can make the pilot believe of being:

options.text: higher than actual altitude with the risk of landing short (ducking under).
higher than actual altitude with the risk of overshooting.
lower than actual altitude with the risk of overshooting.
lower than actual altitude with the risk of ducking under.

A pilot is approaching a runway which is narrower than the one at his home base and has an upslope. Which impression will be generated and how should the pilot react?

options.text: The pilot may have the impression to be above the correct approach path, resulting in an increased rate of descent and possible undershoot. He should believe his instruments.
The pilot will feel that he is further out on the descent path and may reduce thrust too late, resulting in overshoot. He should pay careful attention to his approach speed.
The pilot may believe that he is flying too fast, resulting in an early thrust reduction and lack of energy. He should be careful not to reduce below the specified approach speed.

The pilot will be able to correctly assess his relative position and speed, but he may be unaware of the increased landing distance required. He should consult his performance charts before the flight to ensure that he can safely land at the aerodrome.

variant.question:
<div>During a lesson in a disorientation trainer with no external vision, a student is told to move the head up and down while the training device rotates about the vertical axis. 
  
 Why, during this manoeuvre, does the student suddenly feel dizzy and disoriented?

options.text: Because the training device is rotating, and without outside vision, the interaction between the senses is disturbed when the head is moved.
The head movement itself has no effect on the disorientation; the rotation of the student about the vertical axis in combination with no outside vision alone account for the disorientation.
The head movements disturb the equilibrium between all sensory inputs, and after a certain period of time, the human brain is no longer able to compensate for this.
<div class="WordSection1">The head movements disturb the processing of sensory inputs in the cerebral cortex areas of the student's brain, and subsequently, spatial orientation is lost.

A captain is flying towards the destination airport with an inexperienced copilot. They receive an ATIS announcing CB with associated severe turbulence and windshear. The captain summarises: “We are almost at our crosswind limit; if you can see the runway, then we can make it.” The copilot perceives flashing lights, he/she believes that they could be the runway and makes an approach to land.
This scenario is NOT an example of

options.text: The captain allows the copilot to make the decision to improve his/her little experience in poor weather.
The copilot wanted to conform with the captain.
Risky shift; the tendency of both pilots to take more risk than any of them would on his/her own.
Group polarization (neither pilot wants to disagree with the other).

variant.question:
During their approach, the crew of a Lockheed Tristar noticed that a green light indicating a locked nose gear had failed to illuminate and requested permission to enter a holding pattern for troubleshooting. They were assigned a position over an uninhabited swamp area, which was completely dark that night. While all the crew members were occupied with the landing gear indicator, one of the pilots inadvertently knocked a control wheel, bringing the aircraft into a gradual descent, which went unnoticed. The air traffic controller discovered that the aircraft had descended to 900 ft and asked if there was any trouble, but did not mention the altitude loss directly. The crew confirmed that everything was alright. Only seconds before the crash, the first officer realised that they were descending into the swampland, but the crash could no longer be prevented at the stage.
Select the statement which is NOT true with regard to the above-mentioned accident:

options.text: One of the major errors in the chain of events was due to environmental capture.
According to the SHELL model, a mismatch between liveware and hardware has contributed to the accident.
The chain of errors could have been broken by explicit communication.
The accident could have been prevented by good CRM practice.

variant.question: When flying over a downsloping terrain towards a flat runway, what is the pilot's perception?

options.text: He may feel that he is lower than he actually is.
He may feel that he is higher than he actually is.
He perceives a normal approach.
He may feel that he is going too fast, so he reduces power.

variant.question:
An aircraft departs for a VFR flight. The route involves a descent into mountainous terrain. 
 En-route an instrument fails, which makes it more difficult to fly without visual reference, and the weather deteriorates to IMC. 
 The pilot continues to attempt to fly under VFR but crashes into the mountains. 
  
 What type of error best characterizes this accident scenario?

options.text: Error chain.
Design-induced error.
Lapse.
Isolated error.

variant.question: A pilot successfully completes a difficult and stressful landing at an aerodrome The next time a landing is attempted under the same conditions and at the same aerodrome, the pilot is likely to experience

options.text: a lower level of stress.
a higher level of stress.
the same stress level as the first landing.
the pilot should only attempt a landing at the same aerodrome if the conditions are improved.

variant.question: An aircraft is flying VFR to an airport in mountainous terrain. En-route, an instrument fails, making it more difficult to navigate without reference to visual landmarks. The weather deteriorates to IMC. The pilot tries to continue under VFR, but eventually crashes into the mountains. Which type of error has happened in this scenario?

options.text: Error chain
Design-induced error
Lapse
Isolated error

variant.question: During training the instructor suddenly cuts power to simulate an engine failure. Initially the student freezes down, but then responds quickly and executes a perfect landing. Later, when discussing it, the student feels tired but excited by the situation. What does he exhibit?

options.text: Fight-or-flight response, associated with adrenaline secretion for a rapid response to a stressor.
Alarm phase, which is associated with coping with sustained stress.
Resistance phase, which is associated with instantaneous arousal and reaction.
Exhaustion phase, associated with elimination of toxins produced by the stress, like adrenaline and cortisol.

variant.question: During training the instructor suddenly cuts power to simulate an engine failure. Initially the student freezes down, but then responds quickly and executes a perfect landing. Later, when discussing it, the student feels tired but excited by the situation. What does he exhibit?

options.text: Fight-or-flight response, associated with adrenaline secretion for a rapid response to a stressor.
Exhaustion phase, associated with elimination of toxins produced by the stress, like adrenalin and cortisol.
Alarm phase, which is associated with coping with sustained stress.
Resistance phase, which is associated with instantaneous arousal and reaction.

variant.question:
Pilots receive one engine failure indication; they are on Instrument metrological condition (IMC),
experiencing moderate to severe turbulence, and they are 30 minutes behind their approach time. 
What should they do?

options.text: Pilot should be cautious as this may turn into a chain effect, and should prepare precautionary measure
Contact ATC, and ask for assistance/advice.
Ignore the Indication, as it may be a fault in the instrument.
Both focus in solving the problem.

variant.question: If you approach an airfield VFR at a prescribed altitude, exactly following the approach procedure, and you encounter no unexpected or new problems you show

options.text: skill based behaviour.
rule and skill based behaviour.
rule based behaviour.
knowledge based behaviour.

variant.question: You are approaching an upsloping runway on an inclined mountain without instrument guiding systems. What should you do?

options.text: Fly higher than normal with a less steep approach.
Fly lower than normal with a steeper approach.
Fly higher than normal with a steeper approach.
Fly lower than normal with a less steep approach.

variant.question: An aircraft is on approach and experiencing bad weather conditions very close to the limits. The Captain says I think we can make this I can see the runway now! The Co-pilot says he is not visual yet, then at the last minute he says oh yes I can see it now and they continue the approach to land. What behaviour are they displaying?

options.text: Group Risky Shift
Good teamwork
Experience based decision making
Crew cultural affirmation
